title: Although Anne of Cleves's marriage to Henry VIII was annulled, why did Henry VIII still like her as part of his court? - Quora

response.answer_text: Anne of Cleves was the living counterargument to Henry’s enemies claiming he was a sadistic bloodthirsty jerk who killed his wives when he was bored or angry (directly and indirectly; many blamed Katherine of Aragon’s ill health and death on how cruelly Henry cut her household in an attempt to punish her, Jane Seymour died in childbirth producing that son he was so desperate for, and of course everyone knew what happened to Anne Boleyn.) When Henry decided, for whatever reason, he was not interested in being married to Anne of Cleves, be it her looks, her inadvertently insulting him on their first meeting (she had no idea he was showing up and playing a game of disguise, he assumed she was being rude and disrespectful on purpose), or his just having decided he wanted the teenage Katherine Howard instead, he set his people looking for a way out, just as he’d done with Katherine of Aragon. Just as with her, they “found” something. In Katherine’s case, she’d refused to agree, rightfully from her point of view, and the “King’s Great Matter” had gone on and on. With Anne Boleyn, he didn’t take any chances-when she didn’t go quietly, he had an anointed Queen of England convicted of trumped-up charges and executed. Anne of Cleves wasn’t stupid. She knew that protesting wasn’t going to do anything other than make Henry angry. And an angry Henry could be a very deadly Henry. Even in the best-case scenario, where he didn’t want to enrage the Protestant league nations and simply sent her packing back to her brother, she’d be tainted goods, unlikely to be a good marriage prospect for anyone, and entirely at the mercy of her likely-annoyed family. So unlike her predecessors, she capitulated. She expressed great sorrow and reluctance at losing such a “great” husband, but of course he was right and a precontract existed, meaning their marriage was invalid. A terrible thing, but of course she agreed to it being officially dissolved. This was exactly what Henry wanted: someone who didn’t argue with him, who didn’t make his life difficult, who didn’t scream or demand or invoke the authority of the Emperor or the Pope. Anne dutifully accepted her divorce. So Henry, being Henry, demonstrated to the world how amazingly well he’d treat a woman who did as he asked. He gave her a household, an income, servants, a place at court, and even directed she be considered the King’s beloved sister. When his enemies brought up his treatment of Katherine of Aragon or Anne Boleyn, he could point to Anne of Cleves and say “Don’t be ridiculous! See how benevolent I am to a truly obedient and honorable woman. If they had been dutiful and penitent and recognized the rightness of my argument, they could have had a comfortable life.” That Anne of Cleves was really pacifying a homicidal jerkass who had outright executed one wife and driven two others to their deaths less directly would have gone right over his head.

Because she was pleasant. She got along with him. She didn’t create a scene. An ecclesiastical inquiry into her marriage was duly commissioned, and a delegation of councillors arrived at Richmond in early July to seek Anne’s co-operation. Shocked by this sudden turn of events, Anne fainted. When she had sufficiently recovered herself, she steadfastly refused to give her consent to the inquiry. Before long, though, perhaps fearing a similar fate to Catherine of Aragon or, worse still, Anne Boleyn, Anne resolved to take a pragmatic approach. The marriage was duly declared illegal on 9 July, and the annulment was confirmed by parliament three days later. Anne wrote a letter of submission to the king, referring to “your majesty’s clean and pure living with me”, and offering herself up as his “most humble servant”. “Anne was to be richly rewarded for her compliance. She was given possession of Richmond Palace and Bletchingly Manor for life, together with a considerable annual income. This was further boosted by her right to keep all of her royal jewels, plate and goods in order to furnish her new properties. Moreover, she was to be accorded an exalted status as the king’s ‘sister’, taking precedence over all of his subjects, with the exception of his children and any future wife that he might take.” The marriage was duly declared illegal on 9 July, and the annulment was confirmed by parliament three days later Henry later granted her some additional manors, including Hever Castle, the former home of Anne Boleyn. This was to become her principal residence, and she lived very comfortably there on the fringes of public life. It says much for Anne’s strength of character that she managed to accept and adapt to her new life with dignity.“ “After the death of Catherine Howard speculation began at once about who would be the king’s next wife. Among the potential candidates was Anne of Cleves. She had been careful to remain on good terms with Henry after their annulment, and had shown no signs of resentment at being so humiliatingly rejected. She had been a regular visitor to court and had also received several visits from her former husband, which by all accounts had been very convivial. The pair had exchanged New Year’s gifts in 1542. But the king made no indication of wishing to revive their union, and although Anne was rumoured to be bitterly disappointed when he married his sixth and final wife, Katherine Parr, this may have been just for show.“ “By that time, Anne was comfortably ensconced at Hever with all the riches and honours of being a queen, but none of the disadvantages of being married to the ageing, bloated and increasingly tyrannical king. She remained there for the rest of her days, outliving her estranged husband, who died in 1547.” Later in life they actually got along quite well. They spent much time talking. She outlived all his other wives. I do not know if it was her personality or she saw what happened to Anne Boleyn, but Anne of Cleves did the right thing by Henry. He knew this and reciprocated by doing the right thing by her. https://www.historyextra.com/period/tudor/anne-of-cleves-henry-viii-successful-queen-fourth-wife-tracy-borman/

Anne, daughter of the late Duke of Juliers-Cleves, Johann III, and sister of his successor, Wilhelm, had first been mooted as a potential wife for the English king in the closing weeks of 1537, soon after the death of his beloved third wife,Jane Seymour. Anne was then 22 years of age, and had already been used as a pawn in the international marriage market when she had been betrothed to François, heir to the duchy of Lorraine, in 1527. This had come to nothing, leaving her free to marry elsewhere. John Hutton, ambassador to Mary of Hungary, who had originally made the suggestion, admitted he had heard no great praise of her beauty. Such a recommendation hardly motivated Henry to pursue the scheme any further, and it was not until early 1539 that the idea was resurrected. This time Henry gave it more credence because he desperately needed new allies. Marriage eventually took place. Henry by this time was psychopathic, and his inability to consummate the marriage has been traditionally assigned to his revulsion at his new bride but more likely, due to his various medical conditions and it is at least equally possible that he was impotent. He was nearly twice his young bride’s age and had become increasingly immobile in recent years. There had been no talk of a mistress for some time. This was not the sort of thing that he would have wished to be publicly known. Kings, even more than ordinary men, prided themselves on their sexual potency: it was, after all, vital for the continuation of their dynasty. Henry was a little too eager to boast to his physician, Dr Butts, that although he could not bring himself to have sex with Anne, he had had “two wet dreams.” To the outside world, everything was as it should be. Anne wrote to her family, assuring them that she was very happy with her husband. Meanwhile, Henry made sure that he appeared in public with his new queen as often as could be expected. A few days after the wedding, a celebratory tournament was held in Greenwich. The contemporary chronicler Edward Hall recorded the event and praised the new queen so effusively that nobody would guess there was anything amiss. “She was appareled after the English fashion, with a French hood, which so set forth her beauty and good visage, that every creature rejoiced to behold her.” The new queen was,somewhat awkward which rendered her an embarrassment in the sophisticated world of the Tudor court. There was another reason why Henry was desperate to be rid of his fourth wife. By the spring of 1540, he had fallen madly in love with Catherine Howard, a pretty young lady-in-waiting in his wife’s household. Before long, though, perhaps fearing a similar fate to Catherine of Aragon or, worse still, Anne Bpleyn, Anne resolved to take a pragmatic approach. The marriage was duly declared illegal on 9 July, and the annulment was confirmed by parliament three days later. Anne wrote a letter of submission to the king, referring to “your majesty’s clean and pure living with me”, and offering herself up as his “most humble servant”. Anne was to be richly rewarded for her compliance. She behaved nobly and was given possession of Richmond Palace and Bletchingly Manor for life, together with a considerable annual income. This was further boosted by her right to keep all of her royal jewels, plate and goods in order to furnish her new properties. Moreover, she was to be accorded an exalted status as the king’s ‘sister’, taking precedence over all of his subjects, with the exception of his children and any future wife that he might take.

The mail-order bride Henry VIII chose his fourth wife, Anne of Cleves, from her portrait. He was disappointed by the real woman, but there is more to his change of heart than first appears. Why did Henry marry Anne? He couldn’t get out of it! An alliance with the House of Cleves was a move intended to bring Henry the political support and power that he craved in Europe. He also needed a 'spare' to his heir, Prince Edward. By the time Anne arrived in England the original political reason for the union had diminished, and the lack of any immediate chemistry between Henry and Anne didn’t help. Anne and Henry were also separated by language, culture and personality. They had not met before their betrothal. Henry, who liked to choose his brides for himself (normally from the ranks of ladies in waiting at court) may have already set his sights on Catherine Howard as his next wife. Desperate attempts to halt the Cleves wedding failed, much to the King’s fury. Most embarrassing moment While on her way to London, Anne was surprised by a group of masked men, led by a tall burly middle-aged man who tried to kiss her. Anne, unused to such behaviour - pushed him away in bewilderment. In her embarrassment, she had rejected Henry himself, who was not impressed by her lack of sophistication. The chivalric tradition of meeting your betrothed in disguise was meant to demonstrate true love, as the bride-to-be be would see through the disguise and recognise her beloved. It was not a good start. Wedding nightmare Despite Thomas Cromwell trying to find ways for Henry to send Anne back, the marriage went ahead. The wedding night was a disaster. Wedding nightmare Despite Thomas Cromwell trying to find ways for Henry to send Anne back, the marriage went ahead. The wedding night was a disaster. Anne's innocence and Henry's impatience, combined with his apparently intermittent impotence, meant the marriage was not consummated. Henry persisted for four nights before blaming Anne's unattractive physical appearance for his failure to ‘do his duty’. The marriage was annulled after six months. A happy ending? Because Anne didn’t make a fuss about the marriage being annulled, she and the King remained on good terms. She was rewarded for her acquiescence with a generous allowance and property in Kent. Anne was even invited to Hampton Court for Christmas, where on one occasion she danced with the new queen, Catherine Howard.

Believe it or not, it may come down to that tired old trope, of not feeling “chemistry” but wanting to be “good friends.” Today, we think that outlook can only be true of petulant teenagers but can’t apply to royalty. But think this through… This was Henry’s fourth marriage, and he was getting older. There’s no way to write this without embarrassment, but maybe he felt he needed a sufficiently attractive young bride for him to “perform”; otherwise he couldn’t “rise to the occasion,” as it were. Now, royal children are often told not to care if their betrothed are attractive; it is their job to produce heirs. But Henry was the king himself, and no one could deny his demand to get a sufficiently beautiful bride, if that’s what wanted. And he reportedly was very disappointed when she arrived but (reportedly) didn’t look as good as her portrait. But Henry, though maybe being a narcissist (a common trait of kings with very great power), was not entirely without conscience. So he made sure Anne lived in style… and amazingly enough ended up seeing her as a good friend. By the way, when the next wife was selected for being a young beauty, Catherine Howard, the result was disaster all around… she cheated on Henry and didn’t even deny it but said she “loved a better man” than Henry. Ouch. That had to hurt. Well, off with her head.

Without a marriage contract he did not care for her. Without the pressure of a contract of marriage he came to love and respect her. Henry was a generous man to a fault. Anne appealed to his sense of fairness, justice, and manhood. He was her white knight and saved her from her cruel brother’s wrath had she been sent home. Perhaps she reminded him of a sister that he never had since she was not wife material. Perhaps she was too boring, quiet and not sexy enough for his taste. Instead of creating a disaster, killing her or sending her off to an out of sight castle, he compromised. Besides a lack of chemistry, a hasty marriage, a whirlwind courtship and an Idea of being with her for life, then the marriage was no longer feasible. With his other wives, she was boring. With his other wives, he enjoyed the drama, chaos, and unpredictable nature of his choice in a marriage partner. She is fortunate that she did not lose her head over him.

Because once the pressure to be a married couple was off, Henry found that he enjoyed her company. The thing people don’t get with Henry VIII is that he wasn’t a big womaniser, He was an intelligent man who liked intelligent women. No one expected him to become king so he’d been raised by his mother and sisters, not his father. Once he didn’t have to produce a child with Anne, she became a bit like an aunt to his children and Henry found that he could talk to her. I think it was actually a bit of a relief for him, because she wasn’t allied with any scheming English family trying to get favours from him. Nor did he have to deal with her foreign relatives politically. So he could chat to her without having to watch whatever he said. And she stayed in England because she preferred it to Cleves, I think for much the same reason. I think it was a case of ‘hey baby, I dig you, just not like that…!’

Anne of Cleves was essentially left with two choices. She wouldn’t have been beheaded - her family was relatively powerful and Henry was relying on them and other German Dukedoms to be his allies against Catholic Spain and France) Fight Henry every step of the way and risk a fate similar to Catherine of Aragon. Life in a isolated house, with a poor income generated from said house and reliant on the goodwill and charity of others (and Anne hadn’t been in England long enough to build up that level of loyalty with her Household)Submit to Henry’s will (with a token protest not to seem to eager to get out of the marriage), and be rewarded with a generous settlement, the means to live an independent life comfortably, and retain a place of status at the Court when she chose to attend (even if it means having to set aside any hopes of marriage and children because no man would marry the women who a King couldn’t bring himself to bed).She could see which way the wind was blowing, could see the hand she had to play and played an absolute blinder with them - escaping with her life, wealth and independence… and, perhaps, she was playing that game from the moment she met Henry VIII…

Anne of Cleves didn’t fight Henry, accepted annulment and was always nice and respectful towards him and his family. No resentment from her whatsoever. Hence the King felt like he could still be friendly towards her after annulment. He even gave her choice to either return to Cleves or stay in England and receive generous sum from him. Anne chose to stay. She got indipendence (able to be her own free rich woman) and perhaps living in England was more fun(she was brought up in very old-fashioned household, with strict rules). And she didn’t have to worry about King choping her head off at this point… And of course it made Henry VIII look better if he was getting along well with her, so he often invited her to court, though I don’t think she was at court year round, just special occasions.

One thing to realize about the two queens who he divorced was that both Catherine of Aragon and Anne of Cleves were foreign royals. To kill them would have been risking war with Spain/Holy Roman Empire and a German Duchy. Catherine refused to accept the annulment and as such had to be sent away in exile until her death. Anne of Cleves, on the other hand, accepted the annulment and was rewarded for it. She was also given the Boleyns’ old house and a place as his “beloved sister” or some other courtly nonsense. This made sense because she would have known how to act at court, and she was wise enough to never speak against Henry so he saw her as a positive addition to his court, just not as a wife. I’m sure when poor Catherine Howard was running up the halls crying, Henry regretted not just staying with Anne of Cleves in the first place.

Henry's dislike for Anne was more of bad sexual chemistry, as she was an inexperienced boring young maid and Henry a sexual monster that needed to be fed. Look at his next wife, the fun loving sexually charged 17 year old Catherine. However, Henry could not risk angering Anne and her family that helped run the Protestant league, so he made her a great offer. She got a castle, land, money and could do what she pleased if she would just agree to annul the marriage and become a royal sister. As Anne grew up, got wiser and had fun with it, Henry ended up liking her as a person instead of a wife with all the pressures and pitfalls. They became great friends and some say they had a brief affair…Henry cheated on his girlfriend with his old wife, that's a new one!

I can't believe you really need an answer to this one, Graham, since there are already 34 of them out there, but thank you for the A2A anyway. My impression is that he simply found a relationship with her restful and uncomplicated. He didn't find her sexually attractive, so it was possible for her to be simply a good friend, a friendship with absolutely no strings attached. She was known in Court as ‘the King’s Sister,’ and lived comfortably and safely; she was the longest-lived of his assorted wives, outlasting Henry himself and Kathryn Parr, and his having rejected her as a partner in bed was undoubtedly her luckiest escape. I don't think there was anything more complicated to it than a cheerfully platonic relationship.

She made Henry look good. Her willing and cheerful presence at his court on special occasions was a much-needed contrast to his reputation as a tyrant and wife-killer. At Henry’s first Christmas Court after his marriage to Katherine Howard, Anne attended the celebrations, brought lavish gifts, and made a grand show of the amity between herself and the Royal Couple. It was political theater of the best kind for Henry. And Henry could point to the deference Anne was shown, and the generous settlement he had given her, as proof that he had dissolved their marriage because of his conscience, not because he’d fallen for a nubile teenager. Once the danger of her resisting the end of their marriage was over, Henry actually quite liked her.

She occasionally came to court in the years after she was divorced, usually for a holiday, and sometimes stayed several days. Sometimes Henry went to her home—the one he gave her, and I read that they discussed many ideas and played cards. That was once she had learned the English language. He appreciated the fact that she didn’t resist or make a big deal of his wanting a divorce. She was probably the luckiest of all his wives. She had her own home, servants, money, and independence. That was hard to obtain for women back then.

Anne of Cleves was actually quite smart on this. Anne knew that she could fight Henry’s planned annulment of their marriage, but the odds of success weren’t great. She also knew that Henry could be generous to those who gave him what he wanted. It helped that Anne of Cleves didn’t have a child’s rights and wellbeing in question, or any personal history or sentiment involved, as Katherine of Aragon and Anne Boleyn did, so the choice was a lot easier for her. Look at how it went: Anne agrees to an annulment on the grounds that the marriage was never consummated, and she gets to remain in England (as opposed to being sent home and married off to someone else), is given her own estates, and honoured above nearly every woman in court as “the king’s sister”. All for the price of not putting up a fight. I’d say Anne did quite well for herself.

I think she was one of the cleverest of the six wives no way did she want to be married to Henry we can't know if she planned it, but it's possible she just grabbed the chance to get out of the marriage as soon as it was offered, she didn't fight King henry he must have liked that. He made her legally equal to his sisters and he gave her a generous allowance and lands including Hever Castle she had a good life it said she liked to drink beer and have a good time she was allowed to visit the court any time she liked and was said to have got along with the king's children and his wives

Their first encounter disadvantaged him and he briefly became aware of his limitations. He blamed Anne for this and luckily she escaped with her life. Anne more than made up for her first reaction to him by appearing to be mild and male able to his will. He enjoyed having her non- threatening presence around to remind him of his absolute power of life and death over all his subjects. Keeping her around made him look like the enlightened Prince he had wanted to be. Having her around massages his ego at a time when he was becoming aware of his mortality.

Just because he didn’t like being married to her, didn’t mean he didn’t like her. He called her his sister. He had two actual sisters and he’d been very fond of one of them. I expect he liked having another sister. He liked having Anne around. She was, apparently, good looking, She enjoyed life at the English court. She was smart enough not to annoy Henry. So he was happy to have her at his court.

When he wasn't married to Anne, and the pressure was off Henry soon realised he actually liked Anne he enjoyed her company. He enjoyed helping her learn English customs, ways and improving her grasp of the language, her sense of humour and their shared love of card games. In turn Anne was shrewd enough to expect a generous allowance and home, his protection and friendship and not losing her head.

Because letting her go home would have been a political disaster. Her relatives would have been furious. She was called the King’s sister and wound up a wealthy woman. Her little home kingdom didn’t have much money. It was a big step up.

Quite simply, she gave him what he wanted. She said, “You’re right, Henry VIII, I was precontracted and therefore, our marriage is invalid,” and she was smart enough not to talk about afterwards. She didn’t tell anyone that he was impotent, or that his leg was disgusting. Whether it was genuine or not, she appeared to be loyal and to admire him greatly. She must have been humiliated by the things he said about her but she kept it to herself.

Henry was pleased with Anne because she gave in to him and did what he wanted, so he was inclined to be generous to her. He gave her precedence over all ladies in England except for his current Queen and his daughters, and he called her his ‘sister’. Anne seems to have been a person who was easy to like, both Henry’s daughters were fond of her and continued to be friends with her.

The divorce papers agreed that Anne von Cleves would have an income, and court rank as if she were Henry’s “sister.” That is to say that she would be senior in the kingdom to everyone except the immediate royal family. She was a cheerful woman that Henry actually liked, just not as a “wife.” In essence, he “friendzoned” her. And more to the point, she allowed him to do this to her without making a fuss.

Well, she put up no resistance to a divorce, and underneath, he must have secretly liked her. Henry had been brought up within an female household, and I think he still felt the need to have a woman around around him as some sort of security blanket.

The greatest mystery of all Henry’s girls. I suspect that she was the least sexy and just didn’t interest him as a bed companion but she maybe was just nice and compliant and never got in the way. There are all sorts of love and just maybe she was motherly.

She was the smartest of the six. She gave Henry what he wanted without fuss. She also had endeared herself to his two daughters. Henry came to trust her and her counsel. She came to be an independent and wealthy woman in a time when such was almost unheard of.

Simply put when Henry wanted a divorce, for whatever reason, Anne said “Yes sire, your right sire” (not her real words but the gist of it), Thankful for the easy acquiesce Henry rewarded her. If she wasn’t at first she eventually became one of his good friends.

He came to like her. She made their divorce easy (no histrionics or execution necessary lol) and she was malleable (at least in his eyes). Anne also got on well with his children. I think Anne knew how to play him and seems to have been grateful not to have been sent back home and remarried.
Because she didn't challenge him and went quietly. She was kept in his vourt as respect and financial support.

Because Anne and Henry became good friends after their marriage was annulled, and she was an honorary member of his family and was referred to as “the King's Beloved Sister”. Her not contesting the annulment of their marriage helped her case, and he decreed that she would be given precedence over all women in England save his own wife and daughters. This behavior lends credence to my belief that Henry realized he preferred Anne of Cleeves as a friend rather than a wife and acted accordingly.

She w as considered as “The King’s Sister” because when he wanted out of the marriage, and offered her a great deal of money and other considerations, she took it and gave Henry what he wanted. A divorce.
I think it was political. He was concerned her brother the Duke of Cleves would ally with the Emperor Charles V against him if he was seen to have treated her badly.
Because she was intelligent, witty and had gracefully given him his way without causing a fuss.
Anne of Cleves was an agreeable and conscientious woman, unlike Anne Bolyen. She even willingly converted to Catholicism in order to please Mary Tudor.
Because she was a foreign princess, not a subject of his so that he could do away with her at his pleasure, like he did with Anne Boleyn and later Catherine Howard.
Henry found her repulsive. After he had their marriage annulled though she was kept with the status of a royal p rincess.
She was good to have around. He loved her, divorce etc was political not emotional.
